name: Ultimate Crispy Traeger Wings (Sauce-Ready)
description: A technique-focused recipe for achieving tender, juicy wings with a shatteringly crisp, smoky skin, creating the perfect canvas for your favorite sauce. The key is a two-temperature cooking process and a special dry coating.

ingredients.name: Chicken Wings
ingredients.notes: Split into drumettes and flats, wingtips discarded

instructions: Prep the Wings: Rinse wings under cold water. Pat them completely dry with paper towels. For best results, place on a wire rack over a baking sheet in the refrigerator, uncovered, for at least 1 hour or up to overnight to air-chill and dry the skin further.

Coat the Wings: In a large bowl, whisk together corn starch, baking powder, smoked paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, salt, and pepper. In a separate large bowl, toss the dried wings with oil. Sprinkle the dry mixture over the wings, tossing to get a thin, even, dusty coating.

The Smoke (Step 1 of Cook): Preheat Traeger grill to 225°F (with Super Smoke if available). Arrange wings in a single layer on the grates, not touching. Smoke for 30 minutes to render fat and infuse flavor.

The Crisp (Step 2 of Cook): Increase Traeger temperature to 450°F. Cook for another 25-35 minutes, flipping once halfway through. Wings are done when skin is golden brown, crispy, and an instant-read thermometer in the thickest part reads at least 175°F.
Sauce and Serve: Remove hot wings and place in a large, clean bowl. Pour pre-warmed sauce over the wings and toss to coat. Serve immediately with dressing and vegetable sticks.
cookNotes: The Science of Crisp: The corn starch draws out surface moisture and creates a thin, brittle crust. The baking powder raises the skin's pH, helping it break down proteins for better browning and crisping.
Drying is Critical: Do not skip the drying step. The drier the skin, the crispier the wing.
Internal Temperature: While chicken is safe at 165°F, wings are more tender and juicy when cooked to an internal temperature between 175°F and 185°F.
Sauce Temperature: Gently warm your sauce before tossing. Cold sauce on hot wings can reduce crispiness.
Equipment Needed: Traeger Pellet Grill, hardwood pellets (Hickory, Oak, or Competition Blend), large mixing bowl, wire rack, baking sheet, tongs, instant-read meat thermometer.
